ParentCompanyName: Meridian Management Group of FL, LLC

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



- Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Meridian is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with our regulated processes. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible accidental releases of regulated substances. However, if such an accidental release does occur, we are coordinated with the local Fire Department, Local Emergency Planning Committee, and County Emergency Management Agency for emergency response support.





- The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled



Presently ammonia  (Anhydrous) is the only RMP regulated substance that will be present at this Meridian in a threshold quantity, for which is utilized as the primary cooling media in our closed-loop refrigeration system. The system?s purpose is to provide refrigeration and cold storage capabilities for the Meridian operations.  Due to the  and characteristics of our ammonia refrigeration system, as well as Process Safety Management (PSM) applicability, Meridian is covered under Program 3 of the RMP regulations.



The Worst Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario have been completed as conversed in Section 2 and 3 of the RMP Submit text.



To evaluate both the worst case and alternative release scenarios, EPA's RMP Comp (Revision 1.07) was utilized exclusively. The RMP Comp (Revision 1.07)) model is referenced in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance as an acceptable model for the mathematical approximation process.



As specified in the RMP Guidance, the worst case and alternate case release scenarios have been calculated and the results of the

calculations are on file at the Meridian facility.  Public and environmental receptors that could possibly be affected by the scenarios were determined through the use of LANDVIEW VI mapping system software, and US Census Bureau data. 





- Accident History



Meridian Distribution Center has experienced only one minor accidental release in the past five years.  The documented accidental release did not result in any on site or off site injuries or fatalities. Release was limited to the immeditate area of the release within the Meridian property.



- The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Meridian has taken all necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68.  Meridian is also subject to the OSHA PSM Standard under 29 CFR 1910.119, as well as the EPCRA Section 302 and 311/312 notification/reporting requirements.





- Emergency Action and Response Plan



Meridian's current Emergency Action Plans main focus is on evacuation of the facility in the event of an ammonia emergency.  The facility maintains a written Emergency Action Plan to document specific procedures to be implemented in the event of various emergencies, including ammonia release. The Plan includes procedures for facility evacuation, as well as for notification to the local emergency response agencies, which are responsible for notifying the public.  The Plan also allows Meridian?s personnel trained in emergency response operations to respond to an upset or release. The plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the facility that would require modified procedures.



To plan for an ammonia release with off-site effects, Meridian Emergency Action Plan includes procedures/equipment to mitigate the release, procedures to inform local response agencies, evacuation route maps and procedures for public communication.



In the event of an anhydrous ammonia r

elease with off site effects, the general public will be notified by on site staff and off-site governmental officials.





- Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Meridian's aim is to provide a professional service as efficiently as possible while minimizing the use of toxic materials wherever and whenever prudent.  In this effort our highest priority will be the proactive pursuit of cost-effective process changes that reduce or eliminate the use and/or generation of hazardous toxics at the endpoint of service.  Where hazardous toxics cannot be eliminated, improving controls to handle these substances will be explored and implemented wherever possible.
